an3.51:4.1: Then two old brahmins—elderly and senior, who had lived long and reached the final stage of life, a hundred and twenty years old—went up to the Buddha,
an3.51:4.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side,
an3.51:4.5: “We brahmins, Master Gotama, are old, elderly and senior, we’ve lived long and reached the final stage of life, we’re a hundred and twenty years old.
an3.51:4.6: And we haven’t done what is good and wholesome, nor have we made a shelter from fear.
an3.51:4.7: Advise us, Master Gotama, instruct us! It will be for our lasting welfare and happiness.”
an3.51:5.1: “Indeed, brahmins, you’re old, elderly and senior.
an3.51:5.2: And you haven’t done what is good and wholesome, nor have you made a shelter from fear.
an3.51:5.3: This world is led on by old age, sickness, and death.
an3.51:5.4: But restraint here by way of body, speech, and mind is the shelter, protection, island, refuge, and haven for the departed.”
an3.51:6.1: “This life, so very short, is led onward.
an3.51:6.2: There’s no shelter for someone who’s been led on by old age.
an3.51:6.4: you should do good deeds that bring happiness.
an3.51:7.4: as the good deeds done while living.”
